context: In the case of monoaromatic compounds and low mass PAHs, previous works have indicated that volatilization can contribute significantly to their removal from the liquid phase in the activated sludge process (Byrns, 2001; Fatone et al., 2011; Metcalf and Eddy, 2003; Lee et al., 2004; Yin et al., 2010). Currently, one of the main objectives is to find strategies to enhance biodegradation and minimize the non-biotic transfer to the atmosphere (volatilization and stripping). To optimize the treatment of VOC in aerobic biological processes, models have to take biotic and non-biotic mechanisms into account. Biodegradation of mono- and poly-aromatic compounds needs the acclimatization of the microbial consortium, i.e. the development of a significant fraction of the community that is able to degrade the specific molecule. This is only possible if this substrate is not removed rapidly via a non-biotic process. Among the plant operating parameters, hydraulic and sludge retention time, commonly determine the bioprocess capabilities. Slow-growing bacteria capable of degrading specific molecules are considered to develop above a given SRT value (Clara et al., 2005).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, ethylbenzene is categorized as a monoaromatic compound, which is a type of aromatic compound. The discussion focuses on the biodegradation of mono- and poly-aromatic compounds in activated sludge processes, highlighting the need for microbial acclimatization to effectively degrade these specific substrates. Ethylbenzene's role as a substrate for microbial degradation underscores its classification within the broader category of aromatic compounds, emphasizing the importance of understanding both biotic and non-biotic processes in wastewater treatment.
